instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-3437: What is 820-3437? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.U7100: What is U7100? U7100 refers to the ISL6259 or ISL9239 charging IC on Macbooks from 2013 to the present.
definitions.U7090: What is U7090? This chip is often responsible for creating PP3V42_G3H.
definitions.R7005: What is R7005? resistor between charger and CHGR_DCIN pin of ISL6259, if CHGR_DCIN is low then this resistor is probably blown. When PPBUS_G3H is low or missing this is something to check if your model has CHGR_DCIN along R7005. .
definitions.Q7010: What is Q7010? Q7010 controls whether or not PPDCIN_G3H will be let through to the PP3V42_G3H power supply, often this circuit area is not working because D7010 has died or corroded. .
definitions.R7020: What is R7020? Current sense shunt resistor for the charger, the resistors between this and the ISL6259 should be proper rating or else machine will turn off the charger. Measuring pins 27/28 on ISL6259 should give you 20.02 ohms. .
definitions.R7021: What is R7021? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.R7121: What is R7121? Current sense resistor between charger current sense shunt resistor and ISL6259. When these resistors fail the ISL6259 cannot gauge how much current is being drawn from the charger, which will cause the ISL6259 to stop drawing power from the charger as a safety precaution. Symptoms are low voltage on PPBUS_G3H around 4v, quarter fan spin, or battery not charging..
definitions.3V3_S5: What is 3V3_S5? 3V3_S5 and PP3V3_S5 are interchangeable, see definition for PP3V3_S5. .
definitions.3V3_SUS: What is 3V3_SUS? 3V3_SUS is an abbreviation for PP3V3_SUS. These are interchangeable. The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V3_SUS: What is PP3V3_SUS? The "PP3V3_SUS" rail on a MacBook logic board is a power rail that provides a 3.3-volt supply to the suspend-to-RAM (S3 state) components. .
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: [FONT=arial, helvetica, sans-serif]Hi, this is my first repair attempt on a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B. The measurement on the G3H Fuse is 8.17V which is too low I guess. So I'm thinking that the DC-IN board might be bad. Weird thing is, that the LED on the charger gave  green and orange light, as well as a fan spin some times when I reseated the flex-cable. So the connection seams very fragile there.. What else could it be?[/FONT]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message:
You must get the correct voltage on PPNUS line (aprox 8.5V) even without LIO flex connected.
Only 5pins DC cable is sufficient to start the board.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: [FONT=arial, helvetica, sans-serif]So I`m getting 12,8V on Pin 2 at <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> where I should be getting 18,5V and on Pin 3 for <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> I'm getting 8,17V where IÂ´suppose to get 8,6V...[ATTACH alt="Bildschirmfoto 2018-09-24 um 10.44.16.png" type="full" width="3836px"]39848._xfImport[/ATTACH][/FONT]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message:
"[FONT=arial]So I`m getting 12,8V on Pin 2 at <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> where I should be getting 18,5V"
You make some wrong assumption...
You don't get 18.5V from 45-60W charger.
And also forget about <RESISTOR>R7005</RESISTOR>, which drops a bit the voltage.
Even <TRANSISTOR>Q7010</TRANSISTOR> and <DIODE>D7005</DIODE> itself are between charger and <CHIP>U7090</CHIP> input; where you get 12.8V.

Post some voltages on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>; 12, 13, 9, 15.
Also check voltage and resistance to ground (diode mode) on SCL/SDA pins from J6950.[/FONT]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: [FONT=arial]Ok, so on <CHIP>U7100</CHIP> on Pin 12: 3.36V | Pin 13: 3.36V | Pin 9: 3.36V | Pin 15: 07,06mV?? Regarding J9650 : Pin 5 +6 have shortage[/FONT]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: Sorry ment Pin 5 + 4

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message:
"[FONT=arial]Pin 9: 3.36V"
Muy mal, SMC thinks about overcurrent through <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>.
So check <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR>/22 and traces to U 7100 ;27/28 should give 020.[/FONT]

"[FONT=arial]Pin 5 +6 have shortage[/FONT]
---
Sorry ment Pin 5 + 4"
STOP to measure in diode mode a powered board...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: Ohh, sorry <RESISTOR>R7021</RESISTOR> and 22 are not available on the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: I chekced without power and there are no shorts

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: No shorts on J6950

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message:
I'm sorry too, read <RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>/22.
You should understood what I meant.

Also there is <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR>, instead of <RESISTOR>R7020</RESISTOR>...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: Both(<RESISTOR>R7121</RESISTOR>+22) are 10.3Ohms and have full continuity to the Pin 27 and 28 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: <RESISTOR>R7120</RESISTOR> has 12.6V on all four sides

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message:
Check again pin9 of <CHIP>U7100</CHIP>.
It can't have 3V if there is 20 ohms between pins 27/28!!!

"No shorts on J6950"
I didn't ask to check for short.
Please pay atention to the requests...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: I'm sorry if this gets annoying for you. I checked Pin 9 again(in Voltage Mode) and it gave me: 31mV.  Ok I read out J6950 and here are the measurements: Voltage mode=VM | Resistance to Ground= RG (Diodemode without MagSafe plugged in) --> Pin 5: 3,36V (VM) / OL(RG)    Pin 4: 3,36V (VM) | OL (RG) . Both Pins have very High Resistance to Ground when measured in resistance mode as well. Hope I did everything right this time. I'm a complete newby.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message:
SCL/SDA should indicate something on diode mode.
Check these lines with red probe at ground in diode mode.
You must get less than 1% difference.

"I checked Pin 9 again(in Voltage Mode) and it gave me: 31mV"
So, when can we trust you?
Our help is based on your measurments...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: [ATTACH type="full" width="60%"]39876._xfImport[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full" width="60%"]39877._xfImport[/ATTACH] As I said, I'm completely new to measuring and the whole scene in general, which may be the excuse for this irritating informations. Anyway IÂ´ll try my best and unattached are my findings.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message:
Please do not attach such a big pictures.
Is sufficient to post name/value for the signal...

Do you get <SIGNAL>3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>3V3_S5</SIGNAL> voltage?
Disconnect LIO board, keep only 5pins DC cable connected between MLB and LIO board.
You don't need to connect the flex until get the board turning on first.

BTW, do NOT move that flex again, when the board is powered up...

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: The Flexcable is off since you told me to. I measured 1,8mV on R16101 for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_SUS</SIGNAL> and for <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> I got 1,9mV on <RESISTOR>R8133</RESISTOR>

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message:
So I looked further over the board and found a ripped off pad with a may ripped off resitor (<RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>). The board view and the actual parts are a bit confusing. If there is/was a resistor, any idea if this is cause of my issue and where can I jumper the pad to? Attached are some small pictures
[ATTACH type="full" width="15%"]39881._xfImport[/ATTACH][ATTACH type="full" width="15%"]39882._xfImport[/ATTACH]

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message:
<RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> MUST be present.
Is the pull-up resistor for <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> signal.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: So can I Attach a jumper from pin 1(missing pad) of <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR> to <RESISTOR>R5127</RESISTOR> or am I getting the schematic wrong? If so so, is there a way to jumper the missing pad 1 of <RESISTOR>R5100</RESISTOR>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: I prefer to wire it until <RESISTOR>R5117</RESISTOR>, or <RESISTOR>R5193</RESISTOR>.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3437</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-B bad DC-IN board??
threads.message: Ok so you have 8.17 volts on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. I would assume no green light? If not, SMC is not running check voltage on <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL>
